The sigh of my Muse would you hear,</br>In numbers that flow from my heart,</br>While faint in its progress the year</br>Already's diminish'd in part;</br>The joys of the sportsman, my friend,</br>When thunders the gun in the vale,</br>Too much with calamity blend,</br>My sorrows to lessen or heal.

While shade over shade deepens down,</br>And leaves a fresh carpet supply,</br>The groves, ruffled into a frown,</br>Look ragged and bare to the eye.</br>What tho' the soft pencil of sweets</br>No longer enamels our walk,</br>Supplies not umbrageous retreats,</br>Attracting convivial talk,

Thy mind, with sincerity deck'd,</br>Shall soften my bosom of toil,</br>My narrative hear with respect,</br>Myself to myself reconcile.</br>Although the dun swallows retire,</br>Abscond from our leaf-shedding glades,</br>The beauties of Eve we'll admire,</br>And traverse her far-spreading shades.

Give scope to the picturesque lay</br>While Nature autumnal commands,</br>Rejoice in the year's latest ray,</br>That beams o'er the brown-man seed lands,</br>The season when, Delia, we stray'd</br>To Colin's beneficent dome,</br>Where Charity, soul-chearing maid,</br>To Affliction was ever at home.

Mankind thy most general friend,</br>Sweet seraph of lineage divine,</br>We saw thee thy Colin attend,</br>His heart with thy own to entwine;</br>By Colin the goddess caress'd,</br>Bade tears of distress cease to flow;</br>The pangs of despair were suppress'd,</br>Tho' fixt by some despot of woe.
Through Colin she look'd more serene,</br>Her feelings were Charity's too;</br>Mild, gentle, unclouded of mien,</br>And bright as Aurora's first dew.

How meek is the eve!  let us steal</br>From all the insensible crowd,</br>Who know not the pleasure to feel—</br>Too sordid!  too rich!  or too proud!</br>Autumnus presents us a bower,</br>As yet sav'd from Nature's decay,</br>In friendship to pass the still hour,</br>And yield to Affection's soft sway.

The virgin less bright than thyself,</br>Irradiates the fast-flowing week;</br>My views are not bounded by pelf,</br>Let Delia refrain not to speak;</br>Say Sadness ne'er enter'd the grove,</br>Thin clad in the stole of distress,</br>But Corydon chearfully strove</br>To render anxiety less.

Yet, though unambitious of praise,</br>From want did he never recede,</br>Or covet the garland of bays,</br>But friendship allow'd of the meed;</br>Yet would you believe it, you swains,</br>That Gratitude lagg'd in return?</br>Ye fair, who resort to our plains,</br>And scorn at good-nature to spurn.

You know that when Dorcas applied,</br>O'erwhelm'd with affliction acute,</br>Compassion, untainted with pride,</br>Consider'd, and soften'd his suit;</br>And witness, pale moon, with thy light,</br>Where swims in soft silver thy mien,</br>Autumnus's stores to invite,</br>On wains to the barn on the green;

Did Friendship to Dorcas reply,</br>Yet lulls not his breast to repose,</br>Upbraiding with insolent eye,</br>Exult in his heart-rending woes?</br>No!  scarce had the sun in the west</br>Swept down the broad path of the day,</br>When Corydon found the distress'd,</br>His brotherly love to display.

Ingratitude, sprang you from this?</br>Did sharp-tooth'd Unkindness proceed,</br>Yet ne'er can that heart feel amiss,</br>When Charity sanctions the deed.</br>How oft shall Vivacity say,</br>The child that's been nurtur'd with care,</br>Forgets parent Love to repay,</br>To whom kind return would be dear?

But whither, my Muse, would you rove,</br>The Evening of Autumn your song?</br>To Providence tender your love,</br>For Providence never acts wrong.</br>To bear with ingratitude learn,</br>For acts in themselves their reward</br>Self-applause the most splendid return,</br>Religion and Peace can record.</br>
